Paragraph.Text: JACK (16) is asleep, sprawled across the bed on his stomach, mouth slightly open. A window shows a lightening sky.
GINGER, a sweet Irish Setter with a grey-flecked muzzle, enters frame and licks Jack’s face.
An empty backpack lands on Jack’s chest.
Reveal: PAWPAW (73), a old man with sinewy arms and intense eyes. He wears a green hunter’s vest and camo pants.
Come on, we’re leavin’ in ten. Pack for the cold.
You can leave that thing here too. No service up at Five Ponds anyhow.
Pawpaw tosses Jack something from a duffle bag. Jack catches it. A bolt-action rifle.
Pawpaw drives while eating a McMuffin. Jack eats hotcakes.
When’s the last time you went out?
Think I was nine or ten. We all went out together--you, me, Dad, and Uncle Wyatt. Dad wouldn’t let me shoot though.
They ain’t ever took you out since?
We don’t see Uncle Wyatt much since he moved to Pensacola. And Dad doesn’t like hunting.
What do you mean he don’t like huntin’?
Our family’s been huntin’ in this country for three hundred fifty years--
He just doesn’t like it. I don’t know why.
Jack nods, but can’t supress a yawn.
Jack is still yawning, now dressed in full camo, holding his new rifle. He, Pawpaw, and Ginger amble through the woods.
You woke me up at five a.m.
You gonna give your Pawpaw lip?
‘Nother quarter mile. Set up some salt licks last month on the edge of a field. Place should be crawlin’ with whitetails. Gotta be real quiet when we’re close though. No coughin’, sneezin’, nothin’.
Pawpaw jabs Jack in the gut with the butt of his rifle.
Between crosshairs, past leaves and bushes far to the other side of a field, we see the head of a DEER, its body hidden behind a tree. The deer nibbles grass.
Pawpaw crouches behind Jack, also crouched.
Jack returns to the scope. A beat.
So you ain’t ever popped your cherry?
Uh, no. Dad didn’t want me shooting before I had a license.
Sure he does. Eye on the deer.
The deer emerges from behind the tree. We see her entire body is covered in dark, dried blood. Four red gashes run from her neck to her stomach.
Pawpaw pulls out binoculars and looks at the deer.
What do you think did that?
Bear? Maybe a cougar. But cougars are extinct, least around here...
Can’t believe it’s still walking around.
Must’ve got lucky, I don’t know. Still it’s strange...
Jack’s face sinks. He never thought it would get to this point.
Jack looks into the scope. His breathing gets more ragged.
Jack is white as a sheet. His hands are shaking.
Don’t go getting buck fever on me now. Breathe.
Line up the shot and just slowly, gently squeeze the trigger--not all at once. The shot oughta suprise you.
The crosshairs are trained on the deer. A beat. The crosshairs drift to the nearby tree.
CRACKKK--of the rifle. The bullet strikes the tree. The deer runs off.
Jack lets out a big breath he’d been holding in.
Pawpaw looks Jack in the eyes, sees right through him, but he doesn’t get mad.
Well, it’s getting late. And it’s inauspicious if we don’t bag somethin’ the first day. There’s a lake a half-mile that-a-ways. Let’s go get some duck.
Jack is sitting on a log, plucking the feathers off a trio of dead ducks and frowning. Pawpaw and Ginger approach. Ginger nuzzles Jack sympathetically.
Eh, cheer up kiddo. You’ll get one soon. Just a little buck fever, happens to best of us.
Pawpaw lets Ginger off her leash.
Your daddy used to get buck fever too. Real bad.
Alright c’mon. Pluck ‘em later. We gotta get their livers out first.
A sauté pan filled with simmering liquid, onions, and celery. Three brown duck livers are dropped into the pan.
Pawpaw puts a lid on the pan. Jack is not enthused.
The French call it foie gras. It’s a delicacy over there.
First bag of the season we always eat the livers.
Jack looks at the pan, nervous.
Ginger runs through the forest, exploring. She looks overjoyed to have this much space. She comes upon a creek.
View of the dog From Something else’s Pov
We are moving through brush. From something else’s POV, we see Ginger from afar, drinking from the creek. We hear deep, inhuman breathing.
Sitting at the table, Jack looks down at the liver and onion stew before him. Pawpaw’s already chowing down, but he notices Jack’s trepidation.
Go on. It’s the only dinner you’re gonna get.
Jack picks up a fork, then pauses.
Aw hell son, it’s all just meat. How’re you gonna kill a living thing if you can’t even stomach some foie gras?
Jack plays with the liver in his bowl.
You’re sixteen now. In medieval times you’d already be married. Man up.
What does eating duck liver have to do with being a man?

First of all, growin’ up comes with all kinds of shit you don’t wanna do that you gotta do anyways. Learn that. Second of all, Plato and the Greeks believed that the liver was the seat of all emotions--
Jack picks up a liver with his fork and stares at it.

--which drove men to action--anger, passion, desire, all that. Now obviously we know now that ain’t true, but the symbolism’s meaningful either way. Now finally, and this is most important, eatin’ these livers is a sign of respect for the animals whose lives we just took and the ones we’ll soon take. This all might sound silly to you, but a life shouldn’t be taken lightly even if it ain’t human. So eat.
Jack looks at the liver. He eats some. He chews, frowning. He swallows.
Jack’s face goes green. He gags and runs out the door.
Jack bursts out the door and gags up the liver, leaning one hand against the cabin wall.
Pawpaw stands in the doorway, munching on a liver like it’s an apple.

Text: My first hunt I did the same thing. Although

Paragraph.Text: Jack sees something ahead of him. His face goes from green to white.
My daddy bagged a wild hog, we were down in the Ozarks. Its liver was inflammed or somethin’, it was all squishy and red, stringy, just horrible--
Pawpaw moves to see what Jack is seeing:
Ginger the dog, BLOODY AND TORN UP, limping back to the cabin.
Ginger collapses into Pawpaw’s arms. Her breathing is haggard. She whines.
Jack approaches and peers over Pawpaw’s shoulder:
Pawpaw comforts Ginger. Ginger weakly licks his hand.
Shh sweetie... You’ll be alright... you’ll be alright soon... Shh...
A beat. Jack shakes off his shock and runs off.
Jack flies out of the cabin with a rifle in hand. He runs over to Pawpaw and hands it to him.
A metal case flies open, a shotgun removed... The shotgun is loaded with ammo... A hunting knife is sheathed...
Pawpaw is trying up his boots. He’s all geared up and not one to fuck with.
It’s the middle of the night.
How are you even gonna find it--?
I’ve been huntin’ and trackin’ animals for sixty-five years. I can find it.
For Christ’s sakes Jack, My goddamn dog just died. Stop trying to reason with me.
Pawpaw stalks the forest. Bright red light from a flashlight strapped to his vest illuminates the area. His face is unreadable.
Jack, staring into space, taps a finger on the kitchen table at nervous tempo, not knowing what to do.
Pawpaw approaches a tree gouged with CLAW MARKS. He gets his shotgun at the ready.
Jack looks at the uneaten liver and a half in his bowl on the table.
He groans, then stands. He grabs his rifle on the way out the door.
Cabin still in sight, Jack approaches the edge of the dense forest.
Still no response. Jack considers going back to the cabin. Almost does, but then--
BOOM. From a distant shotgun. Then another BOOM.
Alarmed, Jack hurries after the sound.
Jack enters frame, quite out of breath.
No response. Jack kicks a nearby tree out of frustration--with Pawpaw and with himself.
view of jack from Something else’s pov
Shrouded in bushes, we see Jack kicking the tree from afar. We hear deep inhuman breaths.
We move as if to circle around Jack.
Jack hears the SNAP of twigs from the bushes. He pauses. Raises his rifle.
Jack puts his back to the tree and scans the forest with his rifle. It’s dark and hard to see much of anything.
We are to Jack’s left in the bushes. Jack scans erratically with his rifle, beginning to panic.
Jack pulls back the bolt of his rifle and checks the chamber. He puts it back. His hands are shaking.
Jack fires off a shot far to our left, then panics and makes a break for it.
Jack runs through the forest, aware he is being chased but by what he can’t tell.
Jack hears that and changes direction, running towards the voice.
Jack twists his ankle on a tree root. He yells and falls.
We are moving towards Jack, faster, closer. Jack hears us, grabs his rifle.
Jack can’t believe what he is seeing:
A TIGER stands before him, lit by moonlight. Staring.
The tiger looks emaciated. Its orange and black skin hangs in loose folds. Its ribs are visible.
But the tiger does not attack, just stares.
Jack sees something else about the tiger. Leans forward.
Around the tiger’s neck is a frayed, baby blue DOG COLLAR.
The tiger walks closer, slowly. It drops its head.
Suprising even himself, Jack lowers his rifle. The tiger gets  nearer.
BOOM! The tiger is thrown into a tree as a shotgun blasts its side.
Jack turns to see Pawpaw, shotgun raised and fury in his eyes. His left pant leg is torn, with a bloody thigh beneath. He limps over to Jack, who stands.
Pawpaw is staring at the tiger.
He’s got some kind of... he’s wearing a collar.
Some rich asshole probably bought him as a cub and couldn’t handle him when he got too big. Fuckin’ jackass.
You didn’t have to shoot him...
Pawpaw walks over to the tiger.
Jack approaches and gets a look. The tiger is indeed breathing, just barely. Clearly it’s in immense pain.
Silence. Pawpaw is absolutely firm. Slowly, reluctantly, Jack raises his rifle.
CU on the tiger’s collar. On a tag, we see a name:
Jack stands over the dying tiger, tears welling. Pawpaw stands behind him, looking hungry.
